purpose_overview.goal: Support sustainable fat loss, metabolic health, and cardiovascular protection by applying a moderate caloric deficit to the nutrient-rich Mediterranean dietary pattern.
purpose_overview.approach: Base meals on whole, plant-forward foods, olive oil as the main fat, moderate fish/poultry, minimal red/processed meat, and calorie control (≈15–25% below TDEE).
best_for: Individuals seeking fat loss with high dietary adherence
People preferring flexible, food-varied, lifestyle-oriented eating
Long-term sustainable weight management rather than rapid cuts
purpose_overview.why_it_works: The Mediterranean diet is among the most scientifically supported eating patterns for longevity, cardiometabolic health, and satiety. When paired with calorie restriction, it promotes fat loss while maintaining nutrient sufficiency.

caloric_strategy.maintenance_calculation: Determine TDEE (Mifflin-St Jeor, Cunningham, or wearable devices).
caloric_strategy.fat_loss: 15–25% below TDEE, adjusting based on rate of loss (0.5–1% body weight per week).
caloric_strategy.muscle_gain: Not primary focus, but lean gains possible with sufficient protein and resistance training.
caloric_strategy.body_recomposition: At maintenance calories, protein prioritization + training can support body composition improvement.

macronutrient_breakdown.protein: 1.6–2.2 g/kg/day, from fish, poultry, legumes, yogurt, and eggs.
macronutrient_breakdown.carbohydrates: 45–55% of kcal from whole grains, fruits, vegetables, legumes.
macronutrient_breakdown.fats: 25–35% of kcal (majority unsaturated, from olive oil, nuts, seeds, fatty fish).
macronutrient_breakdown.fiber: 30–45 g/day from fruits, vegetables, legumes, and whole grains.

meal_timing_distribution.meals: 3 main meals + 1–2 snacks within feeding window.
meal_timing_distribution.pre_workout: Carb-rich snack or meal (fruits + whole grains) 1–3 hours prior.
meal_timing_distribution.post_workout: Balanced meal with lean protein + carbs (e.g., grilled fish, quinoa, vegetables).
meal_timing_distribution.evening_meal: Vegetable-rich, healthy fats, moderate protein typical of Mediterranean dinners.
meal_timing_distribution.hydration: Prioritize water; moderate coffee/tea; optional red wine (not advised for everyone).

supplements_optional: Creatine Monohydrate (3–5 g/day) – Strength, recovery, lean mass.
Vitamin D3 – Supports bone and immune health.

monitoring_adjustments.body_weight: Weekly average – Adjust calories by 5–10% if no progress for 2+ weeks.
monitoring_adjustments.strength_performance: Weekly – Ensure adequate carbs for training energy.
monitoring_adjustments.satiety_energy: Ongoing – Increase protein/fiber-rich foods if hunger persists.
monitoring_adjustments.blood_work: Every 6–12 months – Monitor cholesterol, glucose, and vitamin D.

advantages: Strong evidence base for long-term health and disease prevention.
Flexible and highly sustainable for long-term adherence.
Cardioprotective due to unsaturated fats, polyphenols, and plant diversity.
Culturally adaptable and inclusive of many food preferences.
limitations: Weight loss may be slower compared to stricter approaches (e.g., keto, low-carb).
Requires portion control with calorie-dense foods (olive oil, nuts).
Moderate alcohol intake (wine) not advisable for everyone.
Can be costlier than processed-food-heavy diets.
scientific_references: Estruch R et al. (2018). Primary prevention of cardiovascular disease with a Mediterranean diet. N Engl J Med, 378:e34.

Davis C et al. (2015). Mediterranean diet and cardiovascular disease prevention. Prog Cardiovasc Dis, 58(1):50–60.
